abhus: here (in, on, or at this place)
ailte: genitive singular of ailt (“steep-sided glen; ravine”)
airce: genitive singular of airc (“greed, voracity; want”)
airge: genitive singular of aireag (“(faculty of) invention”)
airím: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of airigh
aisig: genitive singular of aiseag (“restoration, restitution; vomit, emetic; returns”)
aitis: genitive singular of aiteas (“pleasantness, fun; queerness; feeling of apprehension; queer sensation”)
amhas: hireling (someone hired to perform unpleasant tasks)
anraí: a male given name from the Germanic languages, equivalent to English Henry
anseo: here (in this place; to this place)
anuas: down, downwards (from a higher position than the speaker)
anála: genitive singular of anáil (“breath; air; influence”)
aníos: up, upwards (from a low position to a higher one), from below
aoife: a female given name from Old Irish, famous in Irish legend and currently fashionable in Ireland
araib: Arabia (a peninsula of West Asia between the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf; includes Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Oman, Qatar, Bahrain, Kuwait, and the United Arab Emirates)
araon: both (after a pronoun or noun governed by a possessive determiner)
artúr: a male given name, equivalent to English Arthur
ataim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of at
atlas: atlas (bound collection of maps; uppermost vertebra of the neck)
atáid: third-person plural present indicative relative of bí
atáim: first-person singular present indicative independent affirmative progressive relative of bí
bailt: Baltic Sea (a sea in Northern Europe, an arm of the Atlantic enclosed by Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Russia and Sweden)
bearú: the Barrow, a river in southeastern Ireland
beilg: Belgium (a country in Western Europe that has borders with the Netherlands, Germany, Luxembourg and France; official name: Ríocht na Beilge)
bhínn: first-person singular past habitual of bí
bléin: groin (long narrow depression of the human body that separates the trunk from the legs)
bocht: poor (of circumstances, of quality, condition, expressing pity, sympathy, expressing dislike, contempt)
brobh: blade (narrow leaf of a grass or grain)
bríce: brick (hardened block used for building; building material)
brúim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of brúigh
buime: nurse (person who takes care of other people's young), nanny
béala: dative plural of béal (used only in certain phrases; see derived terms)
béile: meal (food that is prepared and eaten, usually at a specific time)
bímid: first-person plural present indicative habitual of bí
bíonn: present indicative habitual analytic of bí; "does be"
búrca: a topographical surname for someone who lived in a fortified place.
camóg: comma (the punctuation mark ⟨,⟩ used to indicate a set of parts of a sentence or between elements of a list)
chucu: third-person plural of chuig: toward them
ciall: sense (conscious awareness, sound judgment, natural ability)
cloch: stone (substance; small piece of stone; central part of some fruits, consisting of the seed and a hard endocarp layer)
clíth: heat (“condition where a mammal is aroused sexually or especially fertile”) (in a sow)
coisc: to check (control, limit, halt), restrain, suppress, hold back, hinder
congó: Democratic Republic of the Congo (a country in Central Africa, larger and to the east of the Republic of the Congo)
conán: a male given name from Primitive Irish
crois: dialectal form of cros (“cross; crosspiece; trial, affliction; prohibition”)
crosa: nominative/dative plural of cros (“cross; crosspiece; trial, affliction; prohibition”)
cróit: Croatia (a country on the Balkan Peninsula in Southeast Europe; official name: Poblacht na Cróite)
cugas: Caucasus (a mountain range on the border of Europe and Asia)
cumas: power, capability, ability, capacity, potential, aptitude, competence, faculty (of speech, etc.)
cárbh: where was/would be..., what was/would be
cárta: card (flat, normally rectangular piece of stiff paper, plastic etc.)
cérbh: who was... (triggers lenition of a following consonant)
cíoná: five of trumps (at game of twenty-five, etc.)
círín: crest (summit of a hill or mountain ridge)
cóiré: Korea (a geographic region consisting of two countries in East Asia, commonly known as South Korea and North Korea; formerly a single country)
dalba: bold (presumptuous), forward (without customary restraint), brazen (immodest, shameless), impudent; naughty (tending to misbehave or act badly)
dearc: to regard (look upon in a given way), consider (assign some quality to)
deoir: tear (drop of clear salty liquid from the eyes)
dinge: genitive singular of ding (“wedge; thickset person”)
diucs: euphemistic form of diabhal (“devil”): deuce, dickens
dlite: genitive singular of dlí (verbal noun of dligh)
doirb: small insect or worm, especially one that lives in water; water beetle
dream: crowd, group of people, party (group of people traveling or attending an event together, or participating in the same activity)
droim: back (the rear of the body, especially the part between the neck and the end of the spine and opposite the chest and belly)
drong: body of people; group, set, faction; some
druma: drum (musical instrument; hollow, cylindrical object; barrel etc. for liquid)
duais: a prize (honour or reward striven for in a competitive contest; that which may be won by chance)
dáimh: affection (feeling of love or strong attachment)
díomá: disappointment (emotion felt when a strongly held expectation is not met)
díriú: verbal noun of dírigh (“straighten; direct; aim, point, at; focus on; guide course of; rectify”)
dísle: die (polyhedron used in games of chance)
díslí: plural of dísle (“die (polyhedron used in games of chance)”)
dócha: likely, probable (generally follows the copula is or one of its forms)
dóibh: third-person plural of do: to/for them
dósan: third-person singular masculine emphatic of do
dúinn: first-person plural of do: to/for us
dúras: first-person singular past indicative of abair
eadra: milking time (especially in the morning or late morning)
eagal: feared (used mostly in fixed phrases, see derived terms)
eagán: craw, crop (part of a bird's alimentary tract)
eilís: a female given name, equivalent to English Elise
eisím: first-person singular present indicative of eisigh
eitím: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of eitigh
fabht: fault, flaw; hidden defect; unsoundness at core
faigh: get, obtain, procure, acquire, gain, receive
faram: first-person singular of fara (“along with, beside; in addition to; as good as”)
fiche: twenty, a group of twenty, a score
firín: diminutive of fear: little man, manikin
fogas: only used in i bhfogas (“near, close”)
fonsa: hoop (for a cask, barrel etc.; in a woman's dress; in basketball); any circular band or ring
fotha: a feed; something which is supplied continuously.
frása: phrase (group of two or more words that express an idea but do not form a complete sentence)
fuair: analytic past indicative of faigh (undergoes eclipsis rather than lenition after ní)
fuile: second-person singular present indicative dependent of bí
fáidh: seer, prophet (someone who speaks by divine inspiration)
fíbín: gadding (of cattle: to run with the tail in the air, bent over the back)
galán: cranefly, daddy longlegs (fly of the suborder Tipulomorpha)
gamal: fool, simpleton, goose (silly person), gull (one easily cheated, dupe)
gasra: (band of) young warriors; band of (young) men, of soldiers
geala: nominative/vocative/dative plural and strong genitive plural of geal
gléas: device, appliance, apparatus, contraption, contrivance, instrument, machine, utensil
gnúis: face (front part of head), visage, countenance
goirm: Connacht and Ulster form of gairm
gonta: plural of goin (“wound; stab, sting, hurt; bite”)
gorún: haunch (area encompassing the upper thigh, hip and buttock)
gread: to beat, strike, hammer, pommel, smash, wallop
gróig: to foot (spread out and stack up turf sods)
guanó: guano (dung from a sea bird or bat)
guáin: Guyana (a country in South America; official name: Comharphoblacht na Guáine)
gónad: gonad (sex gland such as a testicle or ovary)
iacób: Jacob (one of the sons of Isaac and Rebekah)
ibéir: Iberia (a peninsula and region of Europe south of the Pyrenees, consisting of Andorra, Spain, Portugal, and Gibraltar)
imrím: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of imir
india: India (a country in South Asia; official name: Poblacht na hIndia)
insím: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of inis
ionam: yam (edible root of a Dioscorea plant)
iorua: Norway (a country in Scandinavia in Northern Europe)
itear: present indicative and present subjunctive/imperative autonomous of ith
ithim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of ith
iósaf: Joseph, eleventh and favorite son of Jacob, by his wife Rachel.
lasca: welt (strip of leather on a shoe)
learg: tract of rising ground; sloping expanse, slope, side
leata: genitive singular of leathadh (“spreading, spread; diffusion, scattering, broadcasting; opening out; dilation, expansion”)
leise: genitive singular of leis (“thigh; leg, haunch”)
leáim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of leáigh
ligim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of lig
loirg: Munster form of lorg (“to track; to print”, verb)
loite: past participle of loit (“to destroy, to ruin, to injure”)
lorga: shin (front part of the leg below the knee), shinbone, shank (lower part of the leg)
luaim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of luaigh
luigh: to lie (be in or assume a horizontal position)
luing: superseded spelling of loing (dative singular of long (“ship”))
lúcás: a male given name from Ancient Greek, equivalent to English Lucas or Luke
mairc: gall (sore or open wound caused by chafing; sore on a horse), sore
matha: Matthew the Apostle, one of the twelve disciples
measa: genitive singular nominative/vocative/dative plural of meas (“fruit, nut, produce”)
meáim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of meáigh
milse: synonym of milseacht (“sweetness; blandness, smoothness (of tongue), flattery”)
miste: of importance, that matters, that one cares about, that one minds about
miúil: mule (offspring of male donkey and female horse)
moscó: Moscow (a federal city, the capital of Russia)
muirn: affection (feeling of love or strong attachment)
murab: if... is not, unless... is (present copular form before a vowel)
máire: a female given name from Hebrew, equivalent to English Mary
málta: Malta (an archipelago and country in Southern Europe, in the Mediterranean Sea; official name: Poblacht Mhálta)
márta: March (third month of the Gregorian calendar)
méabh: a female given name, equivalent to English Maeve
méith: rich (having an intense fatty or sugary flavour)
míním: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of mínigh
niall: a male given name from Old Irish
nicil: nickel (silvery metal, coin worth five cents)
nuala: a female given name from Old Irish
nárab: may... not be (expressing a negative wish)
nárbh: wasn’t/wouldn’t... be? (used to introduce a negative question)
nígir: Niger (a country in West Africa, situated to the north of Nigeria)
oilim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of oil
oirim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of oir
orthu: third-person plural of ar: on them
othar: invalid, patient (person who receives medical treatment)
peann: pen (a tool, originally made from a feather but now usually a small tubular instrument, containing ink used to write or make marks)
peata: pet (animal kept as a companion; person or animal especially cherished)
peige: a female given name from English, equivalent to English Peggy
pilib: a male given name, equivalent to English Philip
preas: press (device used to apply pressure; printed media)
prúis: Prussia (a geographical area on the Baltic coast of Northeast Europe)
puinn: a bit, much/many (followed by the genitive)
páras: Paris (the capital and largest city of France)
péine: pine (tree of the genus Pinus; pinewood)
píopa: pipe (hollow tube; tobacco pipe; large container; computing character)
píosa: piece, bit (part of a larger whole; artistic creation)
reith: heat (condition where a mammal is aroused sexually or where it is especially fertile) (in sheep, goats)
rompu: third-person plural of roimh: before them
runga: rung (crosspiece forming a step of a ladder; crosspiece between legs of a chair)
réama: rheum; discharge of mucus, of saliva; catarrh, phlegm
réidh: level (having the same height at all places), even, flat
róimh: Rome (a major city, the capital of Italy and the Italian region of Lazio, located on the Tiber River; the ancient capital of the Roman Empire)
rónán: a male given name, equivalent to English Ronan
scaid: husks (exterior of certain vegetables or fruits)
scáin: to part (divide in two; become divided in two)
scóig: neck (of a bottle, of land, etc.), throat (of a vessel)
seasc: barren, infertile, sterile (of places and animals, not usually of people)
seift: contrivance, measure (action to achieve some purpose)
seilf: shelf (“flat, rigid structure used to support, store or display objects”)
sicil: Sicily (the largest island in the Mediterranean Sea, an autonomous region of Italy, close to Africa and separated from Tunisia and Libya by the Strait of Sicily)
sifín: blade (narrow leaf of a grass or cereal)
silim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of sil
siria: Syria (a country in West Asia in the Middle East)
slada: genitive singular of slad (“plunder, pillage; spoil, loot; devastation, havoc”)
sleán: slane (spade for cutting turf or peat)
snaga: genitive singular of snag (“gasp, catch (in breath); (convulsive) sob; hiccup; lull”)
snite: past participle of snigh (“pour (down), flow, course; filter through, percolate; glide, crawl”)
sodar: (act of) trotting (walk rapidly; move at a gait between walk and canter)
spota: spot of colour; speck, stain; blemish, stigma; marked spot
spíce: spike (very large nail; anything resembling such a nail; sharp peak in a graph)
spórt: fun, pastime, sport (that which diverts, and makes mirth; pastime; amusement)
srath: holm (rich flat land near a river), bottom (low-lying land near a river with alluvial soil)
staid: stadium (venue where sporting events are held; Greek measure of length)
starr: protrusion (anything that protrudes), prominence (bulge), projection (something which projects)
stoth: tuft (bunch of feathers, grass or hair)
stáca: stake (pointed long and slender piece of wood)
stáin: vocative/genitive singular of stán (“tin; tin vessel”)
sílim: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of síl
sínim: first-person singular present indicative of sín
sómas: ease (freedom from pain, hardship, and annoyance)
tadhg: a male given name from Old Irish, historically anglicized as Thaddeus or Timothy but etymologically unrelated to them.
taisc: to store up, hoard, lay up
teith: to flee, run away, fly, abscond with ó ‘from’/with roimh ‘from’
tigim: Cork and Ulster form of tagaim (“I come”)
toisc: circumstance (that which attends, or relates to, or in some way affects, a fact or event)
tomás: a male given name from Aramaic, equivalent to English Thomas
trach: trough (long, narrow, open container for feeding animals)
trian: third (one of three equal parts of a whole)
triuf: A club card in a deck of playing cards.
trosc: cod (marine fish of the family Gadidae)
tráth: hour (season, moment or time; set time of prayer)
tréan: strong, powerful with ar ‘over’, mighty, doughty
tréig: to abandon, forsake, desert, leave, fall away from
tslua: lenited form of slua (after an and, in some dialects, after any l or n)
tsrón: lenited form of srón (after an and, in some dialects, after any l or n)
tsuim: lenited form of suim (after an and, in some dialects, after any l or n)
tsíle: lenited form of Síle (after an and, in some dialects, after any l or n)
tsúil: lenited form of súil (after an and, in some dialects, after any l or n)
tuata: layperson (one who is not a cleric; one who is not intimately familiar with a given subject)
tuirc: Turkey (a country located in Eastern Thrace in Southeastern Europe and Anatolia in West Asia)
uaigh: grave (an excavation in the earth as a place of burial)
ulpóg: an infectious disease such as a cold, the flu, etc.
umhla: synonym of umhlaíocht (“humility; submission, obedience; dutifulness, respect”)
áirím: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of áirigh
áitím: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of áitigh
éabha: Eve (the first woman and mother of the human race; Adam's wife)
éilím: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of éiligh (“claim, demand”)
éimin: Yemen (a country in West Asia in the Middle East; official name: Poblacht Éimin)
éinín: diminutive of éan: little bird, birdie
éirim: riding, driving; course, gallop; movement, journey
éirím: first-person singular present indicative/imperative of éirigh
íosfá: second-person singular conditional dependent of ith
ólaim: first-person present indicative analytic of ól
óltar: present indicative and present subjunctive/imperative autonomous of ól
